title-group.article-title: A COHESIVE SHAMBLES: THE CLASH'S `LONDON CALLING' AND THE NORMALIZATION OF PUNK

abstract.p: The Clash's London Calling was released just at the moment when the British punk movement seemed to be imploding. From the earliest reviews, it was received as a musical masterpiece that drew on many styles while still managing to be `punk' in some sense. This article argues that London Calling normalized punk, allowing it to be more than an event: punk could henceforth be assimilated into traditional musical discourse and aesthetics. As a careful balancing act between punk street-cred and mainstream musical values, London Calling allowed a double reading. Punk fans could find in it what they sought: anti-establishment anger and at times a messy, disdainful approach to conventional musicianship. At the same time critics and listeners who had come since the late sixties to assimilate rock into a Romantic (or post-Romantic) system of `art' values could find in it what they sought: stylistic growth, organic coherence, originality, and even a `universal' narrative of struggle, triumph, and redemption played out across the album. It is possible to isolate not only a story, but musical connections between the songs (keys, recurrent motifs, and topoi) all laid out in a logical manner. However, unlike concept albums in the seventies' progressive rock style against which punk reacted, London Calling often calls attention away from its musical coherence, and even its textual coherence, rather than towards it—such as by the last-minute addition of a bonus track that disrupts the narrative and key schemes established earlier. The ease with which the album can be praised in established musical language should not completely obscure its potential (and the general potential of punk) to undercut and confront conventional musical discourse.

Richard Taruskin has argued that Cage extended typical Romantic-modernist approaches to music in his underlying attitudes (Oxford History of Western Music, v. 67-73)
Marcel Duchamp... who later became a close friend and mentor to Cage' (p. 72).
Gendron also notes this connection (Montmartre and the Mudd Club, 237)
Angela Rodel, 'Extreme Noise Terror: Punk Rock and the Aesthetics of Badness', in Chris- topher Washburne and Maiken Derno (eds.), Bad Music: The Music We Love to Hate (New York, 2004), 235-56 at 236
Wall Street Journal, 27 Jan. 1978, p. 9
Robert Christgau, 'The New York Dolls', in Marcus (ed), Stranded: Rock and Roll for a Desert Island, 132-47 at 132
Carson, 'Rocket to Russia', in ibid. 107-17

Marcus himself continued from his 'more history than music' statement that 'but on their final night the music lived up to the history....The music was all bite: you could reach out and touch every jagged note' (Fascist Bathroom, 21).

Pistols' 'Anarchy in the UK' single italicized her claim that: 'This time they were meticulous and their care and atten- tion pays dividends, totally destroying the myth that UK punk rock revels in untuned instruments and sloppiness' (.Melody Maker, 27 Nov. 1976, p. 3).

Pistols? Another reviewer found the Sex Pistols' album 'single-mindedly rocking' and 'artfully simple' and hence effect- ive even without the political component (High Fidelity, Mar. 1978, pp. 128-9).

Paul Nelson in Rolling Stone also praised some numbers as 'near perfect rock & roll songs, classics in the way of the Who's "My Generation"', and heard a number of musical quotations in the album (Rolling Stone, 23 Feb. 1978, p. 48).
Chris Brazier's review of the album for Melody Maker.

Brazier spent several paragraphs discussing the music, praising Steve Jones ('the best musician in the band... superb guitar') and even calling the album a'masterwork' (Melody Maker, 5 Nov. 1977, p. 3)
n. 22 above
Dick Nusser in Billboard called the album an 'unrelenting musical tantrum' but came to like it for shaking up the music industry (Billboard, 21 Jan. 1978, p. 138).

Steve Simels in Stereo Review said of the Pistols' album that musically they were not 'remotely original' and that they were 'loud, crude, minimally skilled at their instruments'—but he also believed the album was 'a small rock masterpiece' because it put across a political message. He concluded by noting that he himself represented 'many of the values they claim to be rejecting.... And so, that I do rather like them indicates a failure on their part, it seems to me' ('The Sex Pistols', Stereo Review, Feb. 1978, p. 132).

Village Voice, James Wolcott reviewed Never Mind the Bollocks, saying that the album is 'an indispensable record, perhaps even a great one' but that 'musically, the record is too monotonously tense and abrasive' and limited in general (Village Voice, 21 Nov. 1977, p. 53).

Jon Savage put it his 1979 write-up of Never Mind the Bollocks for a 'Ten Albums that Shaped the Decade' feature in Melody Maker. 'The actual "musical best" of the Pistols lies, perhaps, in some tape that no-one made... but again, music was not wot it was about...' (Melody Maker, 10 Nov. 1979, pp. 36-7).
Never Mind the Bollocks in Rolling Stone's 'The Top 100: The Best Albums of the Last T wenty Years' (27 Aug. 1987, pp. 45-174)
'Nothing in rock was ever quite the same after...' (p. 48).

Waksman mentions that London Calling 'was the first punk album I owned and would be the only one for some time' because the Clash seemed 'less dangerous' to one who was an outsider to the punk sub- culture than the Pistols were (p. 13).

Sam Sutherland saw in London Calling 'the raw rock energy and street-jive color of Exile on Main Street' (High Fidelity, Apr. 1980, p. 122)
Michael Goldberg in Down Beat invoked Exile on Main Street more simply as a 'masterpiece' ('The Clash: London Calling', Down Beat, 47 (May 1980), 35).

John Piccarella actually called his review 'Clash on Main Street' and noted the most parallels between the two albums: looser construction following carefully produced single albums, expansion of keyboard and horn use in arrangements, expansion of styles, even the 'outlaw-amid-big-business conceit.... Both albums achieve a far-reaching redefinition of rock and roll history within the consistency of one band's style' (Village Voice, 4 Feb. 1980, p. 61).
Scott Burnham, Beethoven Hero (Princeton, 1995)
Ibid., esp. 147-68.
Sanna Pederson, 'On the Task of the Music Historian: The Myth of the Symphony after Beethoven', Repercussions, 2/2 (1993), 5-30.

David Charlton (Cambridge, 1989): 'Mozart leads us deep into the realm of spirits. Dread [Furcht] lies all about us but withholds its torments and becomes more an intimation of infinity' (p. 97, and again pp. 237-8).

'Beet- hoven's music sets in motion the machinery of awe, of fear [Furcht], of terror, of pain, and awakens that infinite yearning which is the essence of romanticism. He is therefore a purely romantic composer' (pp. 98, 238).

William Ruhlmann's London Calling entry in The All Music Guide from 1992 claims the album 'solved [the group's] problem by taking a giant step toward making craftsmanlike rock without sacrificing the urgency that made them punk leaders' (in Michael Erlewine (ed.), All Music Guide: The Best CDs, Albums & Tapes: The Experts' Guide to the Best Releases from Thousands of Artists in All Types of Music (San Francisco, 1992), 74).

Dave Marsh had written back in 1977 that the Pistols' 'God Save the Queen' was 'the most important record of the past year....This doesn't qualify it for immortality—significance is not always art' (from Rolling Stone, repr. in Marsh, Fortunate Son: Criticism and Journalism by America's Best-Known Rock Writer (New York, 1985), 251)

"'We can't play" was the rhetoric, but the Sex Pistols could' (p. 206).

Fredric Jameson, in the context of postmodernism, called the Clash (along with Talking Heads, Gang of Four, Phil [«£] Glass, and Terry Riley) 'later syntheses of classical and popular styles' after John Cage (The Ideologies of Theory: Essays 1971-86, ii: Syntax of History (London, 1988), 104).
